awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Introducing High-School Students to Computational Thinking in Industrial Automation
awd_abstract_narration:
As computing has become integral to the practice of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), the STEM+Computing program seeks to address emerging challenges in computational STEM areas through the applied integration of computational thinking and computing activities within STEM teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school (preK-12). 

A strong manufacturing industry is essential for the nation's economic prosperity. Workers in manufacturing increasingly need to have skills involving the use of computational thinking, software and advanced technologies. The project will develop a series of Digital Invention Kits that will enable high school students to reconstruct working models of the digital counterparts of these inventions. For example, the Davenport Rotary Motor, patented in 1837, will be used as scaffolding for development of a Stepper Motor Kit that incorporates a digital micro-controller. Students will thereby learn about the way in which the original analog electromechanical mechanisms led to development of today's digital counterparts.  The proposed Digital Invention Kits will (1) provide an introduction to computational thinking, (2) recruit diverse students who are not traditionally attracted to STEM fields, and (3) introduce these students to industrial automation. The associated infrastructure developed through these projects will increase the capacity of schools to offer a broader range of manufacturing technologies in K-12 makerspaces. Participation in these programs by a broader range of students will also lead to increased diversity in advanced manufacturing programs in community colleges and beyond. The completed Digital Invention Kits and accompanying pedagogical materials, assessment items, and teacher support materials will be made available on the Make to Learn website and disseminated by professional organizations. The project will also conduct workshops and short courses introducing these materials to technology and engineering educators.

The project will investigate: (1) how effective the Digital Invention Kits in improving computational thinking, (2) how effective the Kits are in engaging and retaining female and underrepresented students for the entire Kit sequence, and (3) how the computational thinking strategies introduced in the program affect student design and product development. The project will use a mixed method approach to assess participant growth in various aspects of computational thinking, using both quantitative and qualitative methods. To examine student thought processes and solutions, the project will use qualitative approaches to study computational strategies, actions, coding and products, along with rationales and related beliefs. These will include observations of students, artifact analyses, task-based interviews, STEM-focused interviews, and instructor assessments (including tests and final course grades. Research outcomes will be presented at STEM conferences and will be published in peer-reviewed journals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to meet a significant workforce development need by encouraging a larger and more diverse population of high school students to consider STEM careers in manufacturing technology jobs. In this collaborative project, teams from the University of Northern Colorado (UNC), the University of Virgina (UVA), Aims Community College (Colorado), Blue Ridge Community College (Virginia), and a local STEM high school in Northern Colorado worked together to develop and test learning activities based the Make to Learn Art, Animations, and Music curriculum (https://maketolearn.org/creating-art-animations-and-music/). The activities were designed to engage students in authentic STEM learning focused on computational thinking to spark interest in manufacturing and technology careers. The learning activities were designed at UVA and implemented first at Blue Ridge Community College, modified by the Colorado project partners, and tested in a high school STEM course and at an Aims Community College summer STEM program.

Over the course of two cycles of implementing the learning activities with high school students in a STEM course, we collected data on students’ confidence and self-efficacy in STEM areas, their 21st century skills, and interest in STEM careers. Informal interviews with teachers and students were conducted to identify aspects of the learning activities that were most engaging to K-12 students, how the curriculum aligned with the Science and Engineering Practices (SEP) in the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS), and teachers’ self-efficacy for teaching the STEM lessons. Overall findings showed that students’ self-efficacy and interest in STEM careers increased after completing the learning activities. However, teachers reported they needed more support to effectively teach STEM learning activities that included computational thinking in the context of industrial automation.

In addition to implementing the learning activities in a high school STEM classroom, 40 high school students from the local school district participated in a summer STEM program designed and led by Aims Community College faculty. The summer program activities were related to those enacted during the school year but also included having students use manufacturing technology available on the community college campus. Students worked in teams on a variety of projects focusing on industrial technology, robotics, 3D-printing, general science, and critical thinking to learn about technology and how it is used in industry. Survey results from the summer program measured changes in students' confidence and self-efficacy in STEM areas, 21st century skills, and interest in STEM careers. Results indicated that after attending the program, students’ interest in STEM careers increased as well as their interest in programming offered at Aims Community College. During the summer program, the UNC post-doctoral researcher was a participant observer. Observations corroborated the survey results that students’ confidence and self-efficacy for STEM increased after participating in the program.

Based on these results, the makerspace created at the University of Northern Colorado for this project was expanded for a post-doctoral research assistant to support 47 undergraduate students (future teachers) enrolled in the teacher preparation program at UNC to complete the learning activities and collect data to identify the supports necessary for teachers to implement the activities in K-12 classrooms.  The future teachers completed a short, open-ended survey before and after completing the activities. The survey questions included whether they felt confident using making technology (e.g., 3D printers, laser cutters, microcontrollers), teaching students how to use 21st Century technology, as well as their experiences and confidence in coding during the digital art activities. We found gains in all participants’ self-efficacy and this project supports the claim that digital arts learning activities that infuse educative making can be used to develop and strengthen self-efficacy for using technology in STEM education. In addition, an inductive, qualitative content analysis approach was used to identify common themes that emerged. At the beginning of the study, the future teachers were apprehensive and unsure of their abilities to use makerspace technology to teach activities focused on computational thinking. However, at the conclusion of the project, all participants expressed a belief that technology use and coding were important skills for students to learn, in part because their students would likely need them in their future careers. We also found positive gains in the future teachers’ self-efficacy for using technology to engage students in NGSS Science and Engineering Practices. Most importantly, they reported that the activities supported their understanding and ability to develop activities for learners that focused on science and engineering practices, specifically Using Mathematics and Computational Thinking, a practice that is often difficult to teach and incorporate in science curricula.

Our overall project findings indicate there is a need for discussions within the science teacher education community about how to meaningfully infuse technology integration across teacher preparation programs and teachers need support to develop their own technological literacy to successfully teach the STEM learning activities that include computational thinking in the context of manufacturing.
